name: passer-domesticus
definition: The house sparrow is a bird of the sparrow family Passeridae, found in most parts of the world.
description:
It is a small bird that has a typical length of 16 centimers and a mass of 24 to 9.5 grams.

Females and young birds are colored pale brown and grey, and males have brighter black, white, and brown markings. Underparts are pale pearly-gray.

One of about 25 species in the genus Passer, the house sparrow is native to most of Europe, the Mediterranean Basin, and a large part of Asia.

Its intentional or accidental introductions to many regions, including parts of Australasia, Africa, and the Americas, make it the most widely distributed wild bird.

It was introduced into North America at Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1852 and within a century had spread across the continent.

The house sparrow is strongly associated with human habitation, and can live in urban or rural settings.

Though found in widely varied habitats and climates, it typically avoids extensive woodlands, grasslands, and deserts away from human development.

It feeds mostly on the seeds of grains and weeds, but it is an opportunistic eater and commonly eats insects and many other foods.

Its predators include domestic cats, hawks, owls, and many other predatory birds and mammals.

House sparrows form monogamous pairs for each breeding season. Nests are built between February and May.

They nest in crevices inside and on buildings, and in coniferous and deciduous trees. Nests are built from dried vegetation, feathers, strings, and paper.

Eggs are layed at any time in the nesting period. One to eight eggs can be present in a clutch, with the possiblity of four clutches per nesting season.

Incubation begins after all the eggs have been layed. Both males and females incubate the eggs for short periods of a few minutes each.

Incubation lasts for 10 to 14 days. After the eggs are hatched, both males and females feed the young through regurgitation.

Because of its numbers, ubiquity, and association with human settlements, the house sparrow is culturally prominent.

It is extensively, and usually unsuccessfully, persecuted as an agricultural pest.

It has also often been kept as a pet, as well as being a food item and a symbol of lust, sexual potency, commonness, and vulgarity.

Though it is widespread and abundant, its numbers have declined in some areas.

The animal's conservation status is listed as least concern on the IUCN Red List.

featured.caption:
The top of a male sparrow's head is dark gray lined with streaks of vibrant chestnut, while a female's head is more dusty brown in color.

Look at the throat. Male sparrows have a black band at their throat, while the female's throat is a pale brown.

facts.name: Adapted to the life in human settlements
facts.value: One of the reasons why sparrows adapted to the life in human settlements is constant supply of food. Sparrows easily learned to eat "served food" when people started to build bird feeders.

facts.name: Sparrows are not territorial animals
facts.value: Sparrows are not territorial animals, but they will aggressively protect their nest from other sparrows.

facts.name: Survive between 4 and 5 years in the wild
facts.value: Sparrows can survive between 4 and 5 years in the wild.

facts.name: Sparrow has stout body
facts.value: Sparrow has stout body, covered with brown, black and white feathers. Its wings are rounded.

facts.name: Sparrows have several broods each year
facts.value: Sparrows have several broods each year. Female lays 3 to 5 eggs. Incubation period lasts 12 to 15 days. Both parents take care of the eggs and chicks. Young birds are ready to leave the nest 15 days after birth.

facts.name: Usually fly at the speed of 38 km/h
facts.value: Sparrows usually fly at the speed of 38 kilometers per hour. When needed (in the case of danger), they can accelerate to the speed of 46 kilometers per hour.

facts.name: Sparrows are carnivores by nature
facts.value: Sparrows are carnivores (meat-eaters) by nature, but they have changed their eating habits when they learned to live close to people. Sparrows primarily eat moths and other small insects, but they can also eat seed, berries and fruit.

facts.name: Male is responsible for building of the nest
facts.value: Male is responsible for building of the nest. During construction, male will try to attract female. She can help in further building if she is interested in mating.

facts.name: Males and females slightly different colored
facts.value: Males and females can be distinguished by the feather coloration: males have reddish backs and black bib, while females have brown backs with stripes.

facts.name: Usually build nest under the roofs
facts.value: Sparrows usually build nest under the roofs, under bridges and in tree hollows.

facts.name: Main predators of sparrows are cats
facts.value: Main predators of sparrows are dogs, cats, foxes and snakes. Young and inexperienced birds are the main target and easy meal for these carnivores.

facts.name: Sparrows can swim very fast
facts.value: Although sparrows do not belong to the group of water birds, they can swim very fast to escape from the predators.

facts.name: Sparrow is a very small bird
facts.value: Sparrow is a very small bird. It can reach 14 to 18 cm in length and 24 to 39.5 grams in weight.

facts.name: Sparrows are allegedly monogamous
facts.value: Sparrows are allegedly monogamous. Recent genetic analysis showed that only small percent of eggs contains DNA of both parents (in other words: both male and female are prone to infidelity).

facts.name: Live in colonies called flocks
facts.value: Sparrows are very social and they live in colonies called flocks.

related.definition: A North American bird having a crested head, a short thick bill, and bright red plumage in the male.
The common house martin is a migratory passerine bird of the swallow family.
A widely distributed bird that nests in barns and caves and has a deeply forked tail, a dark-blue back, and tan underparts.
The common nightingale is a small passerine bird best known for its powerful and beautiful song.
